It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan. Here, you transition from farmland to small tourist towns. There are no big city malls, no Walmart, Target, or even Applebee's. You have to drive to get anywhere you want to go. Despite that, I reside in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water, with beautiful Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood reflects the essence of a small town. Houses are not stacked on top of each other, nor are they cookie-cutter homes. They are older houses, some updated and remodeled, and others more aged. Most homes have full basements visible from the street. Many houses in the area have older aluminum siding. We have houses in every color imaginable surrounding mine. Most of the houses have yards, complete with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their animals. The houses represent Middle America—hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having raised them. On any given day, you'll see kids running up and down the streets. You'll also see people walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who fits in and who doesn't. You might see someone grilling outside and waving, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away smiling pleasantly. The lawns are well-maintained, with no piles of leaves left from autumn. Green grass is kept mowed and tidy. If there are plants and bushes in the yards, they are kept trimmed. It's not a neighborhood that you drive into and think "wow," but rather one where you feel it would be a good place to raise a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe. While not striking in appearance, it stands out because it embodies what people desire—a safe haven at the end of the day. Within walking distance are the county sheriff's department and jail, with the health department next to it. The city recycling center is just down the road, and neighbors and residents from the city use the services they provide. Nearby, we have baseball and softball fields where you can hear announcers keeping score and calling players' names. Our small-town airport is right next to it. Whether playing outside or inside, you can hear the rumble of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and if you're inclined, you can reach downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, which is only about 8 blocks away. It's a truly wonderful place to live.

The area where I live can be described as a typical cookie-cutter suburb. In my particular neighborhood, the presence of a homeowner's association is very noticeable. Upon entering, you'll see only well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the homeowner's association. The front yards are all quite similar, featuring a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and relatively short driveways. Occasionally, you'll spot small trees as well. Everyone has a two-car garage. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition, free of potholes. Most houses are single-story, but occasionally you'll see two-story ones as well. We don't have the typical mailbox setup you might expect for single-family homes. Instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, there is a cluster of mailboxes at the end of the street, more like an apartment setup. Each person uses a key to access their specific mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. Again, this is thanks to the HOA's obsession with uniformity. My house is located on the edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburban. As a result, we have plenty of land for everything. There are multiple community pools that anyone living here can access. They are well maintained and gated. There are also various walking trails where you can walk your dog or take a stroll by yourself in the evening. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it to get a good workout. Most of the community consists of retired people. It's a very safe area, with everyone looking out for one another. Alongside them, there are also a few middle-aged and young professionals. As for the city, it's surprisingly large—at least in terms of population—but still retains a small-town feel. We have most of the amenities you'd expect and rely on. For instance, we have one mall. It's not huge, but it serves its purpose. For me, it takes about 15 minutes of driving to reach any significant destination, but once there, I'm greeted with a variety of stores to choose from. We have everything from high-end grocery stores where you can buy organic food to discount outlets that carry a small selection of items and have minimal staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and quite typical. We have many nice features, like pools and walking trails. And although we're not right next to any shopping centers, you can easily drive to any major chain you like.

The first time I heard about my apartment was on a podcast about missing people, which surprised me a bit. Almost every apartment in the area costs over a thousand dollars a month. Neither I nor my friends had heard of that story before. Maybe it's the hardship of life. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but over the years we have learned to be frugal. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You notice fewer smells as an adult. You might start smoking or perhaps just get used to it. But the flea market is always there. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano, which stays in the leather even after washing. There are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from afar, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you wouldn't hear that in the thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store remains silent. It's a great place to lose an afternoon. Each year, more places like this emerge. Cars and people flood in. They say it's a developing city, home to a major online e-commerce and delivery empire, yet it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything is pursuing their own goals, and few ask much from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people leave you be. It's not like the South, where showing some concern means you care. You don't really pry into others' lives here. You can keep your shell as long as you like, and the city will crash and recede like waves on the shore. It's a lively place. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, something is always happening. In a way, our apartment feels less like a group of strangers and more like a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In some ways, I'm lucky to be here. I like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same for me. I bring them their mail, and they bring mine. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a vast, dehumanizing modern sprawl, but people like my neighbors make me feel like I haven't completely ruined my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town just outside the suburbs of a major city. My neighborhood, located on the east side of town, is considered the most economically disadvantaged area. Property values are low, with most houses rented or owned by low-income individuals. However, the area is neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly, often smiling and greeting me as I walk by. While crime rates are slightly higher than in other parts of town, they remain generally low. Over the past ten years, there have been a few violent crimes within a few blocks of my home, including several shootings and at least one homicide. Last year, our neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar. Luckily, apart from occasionally losing an item left on our porch, our family has not been directly affected by crime. Overall, the town has been significantly impacted by the opioid epidemic affecting many parts of the U.S., with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, our town offers many resources to combat this crisis, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, the town has many positive attributes. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support personnel. Despite having special needs, he has not experienced any bullying due to the school's incredibly positive atmosphere, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that organizes various events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. With more than 20% of our town's population living below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No child or family is treated as inferior due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to our town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most improvements have been concentrated in the town center and west side, where the shopping areas are and most traffic passes through. The east side, where I live, tends to be overlooked, which is a point of contention in my neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, there are sufficient shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family's needs, and while our home may not be highly valuable, it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years and cannot imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It's located on a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical significance. I live in a 7-story apartment building directly across from an old live theater, and just a block down the hill is a neat little arcade bar that attracts various people on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekends in June and July, you'll see lines of people waiting to enter. A few blocks up is the nearest city park, which is quite large for this part of town. The park is bordered by concrete, with tall steps built into the wall. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in tidy rows along the sidewalk and wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the heavy downpours in mid-winter often make it hard to stay warm. By setting up their tents close together in the city center rather than out in the wilderness, they stay much warmer. They are also within a reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city isn't the beauty of its historic nature—the tall, proud buildings and the architecture scattered across the hills that roll down to the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. Hilltop was once the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. Even three decades later, you still hear stories of federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people don't forget. Stories are passed down from generation to generation, even to newcomers like me, about those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the tougher areas in the city, to keep it clean. They still care about what happens in their city and on their block. They say if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. I believe this warning echoes the past, tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps I am dark enough to not entirely appear as a "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who is painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions arise from ignorance and fear, even in a city supposed to be a cultural melting pot utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I travel, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more often offered me a jacket than tried to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open a little longer so I could charge my phone when I had nowhere to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believing myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the dreariest of nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood when I was about to start eighth grade. Initially, it was difficult for me to make friends, but eventually, I became close to someone living two houses away and another person on my street. Neither of them lives here anymore, but the memories remain. Most of the people who lived here when I first arrived are still here. My neighborhood is quite similar to a typical American suburban area, with many two-story houses. Every weekend or when it's warm outside, I hear children playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days. I've never had any issues with the people here. In this community, you're left alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online, and none have ever been taken from my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There's a park a minute or two from my house, where I have many memories. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with others from the neighborhood. I also have one of my worst memories there—getting elbowed in the nose while playing football—but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I go to the park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger and still enjoy swings and slides. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park now makes me nostalgic for many reasons. The neighborhood is very diverse. You can find all kinds of food nearby. Within a one-mile radius, there are Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, many people now use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for food delivery. The most popular places are fast-food joints, which you can find near almost any suburban area. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here have everything you might need. There are several dry cleaners nearby. There's a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, popular in the Midwest. Some stores are even diverse, like an Indian-owned store if you're in the mood for homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I really like my neighborhood. Reading social media and news about the horror stories others experience with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, which makes me enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, along with some restaurants and bars that are fun to visit and not too expensive. One bar recently changed its name and is more expensive, but the service and drinks are decent. Most people are friendly, being either college students or low-income individuals since the apartment rent is quite affordable. There are many children nearby due to an elementary school within walking distance. I don't know my neighbors, nor do I wish to, as they smoke a lot of weed, leading the building management to place an air freshener across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found amusing. It's almost an insult. Buildings around me look old but might have renovated interiors. Down the street, there are brand new apartments, but I dislike them because I know their construction quality isn't good. They're cheaply built, yet the rent is high, which I think is a scam, but being near campus lets the management get away with it. There's a very cheap restaurant five minutes from where I live, serving food on paper plates with most dishes microwaved. Across from it is a gas station, reputed to be a poor workplace. However, thanks to city funds, the road was redone last summer, providing a nice big sidewalk and lots of grass, improving the area's appearance. My apartment building is surrounded by trees. They cut down some, leaving stumps, but there are more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, but right behind it is 43rd Street, which isn't as nice. The sidewalks there are in disrepair, and most buildings look shabby. There are many trees on that street, probably to hide the buildings' appearance. Most of the crime in my area occurs at an apartment complex on that street, but I can't solely blame them. There are also apartments with high crime and transient populations across from me. Still, I think I like where I live. It's affordable, and there are plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially appreciate the university being within walking distance and two bus stops that make it easy to reach the store and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes located on a cul-de-sac. They are spaced out in a way that makes them look like separate houses. The only difference is that each one is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone is friendly with each other, though not all. On some evenings, we gather at the end of a random driveway to chat while the neighborhood children play with toys, sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's a refreshing change from the modern, technology-filled world. It feels like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, with blue skies and white, fluffy clouds above. The downside? This season, we've had tornado warnings, and for the first time last night, we actually heard tornado sirens, which meant we had to seek shelter. Sure enough, you would find me in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and a few pillows. My big dog, uninterested in the bathroom, stayed in the living room, nervous and barking at the unusual situation. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road was steaming due to the temperature change. It went from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing sky, the sun emerged and it started to rain, revealing a double rainbow. I rushed inside, grabbed my camera, and took pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. We were all amazed. The streets remained quiet for another hour until people began returning home from wherever they were during the thunderstorm. Then, life returned to normal, with moms and children outside as dinner cooked. It's such a friendly neighborhood for someone like me who recently moved from NH to NC. I adore the southern accents. I have a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, as does everyone else. Although all the houses look the same on the outside, not all the apartments are the same inside. Some are quite small, which puzzles me. I love walking along the largest field behind my home and wandering down to the pond, which isn't for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the morning, you can hear a giant bullfrog's song. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes outside Charlotte. Each morning starts with roosters crowing from nearby farms. It's like living in a small community village. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that brays in the evening to let us know he's there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.

Given that I've been here for around 10 years, I feel I can share my experiences. At first, when I came to my neighborhood, I was quite sad. Moving from Riverdale to Stockbridge made me cry because I missed my old place and loved it a lot. However, my parents wanted the best for my little sister and me, so we moved to a better area with improved housing and a better high school, a place that was considered "not ghetto." Over the years, I adapted and made some new friends, and also some rivals at school. I didn’t really get to know my neighbors well, except for Mr. Glen and his kids, and Dennis who lived next door. They have been wonderful people, almost like family to me, and I truly appreciate them. I remember when my family attended Mr. Glen’s wedding, as he got re-married, which was incredibly enjoyable and something I aspire to in the future as I build a better life for my future wife. When Ms. Veda, Mr. Glen’s wife, tossed her garter, I caught it! Unfortunately, I missed the bouquet. We danced all night, and I especially enjoyed spending time with their daughter, Marsharii, though I haven’t seen her since. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood is like a maze, but with GPS now, I can explore more leisurely. I’ve ventured out mainly with my friends Kason and Curtis, playing video games and enjoying life to the fullest. Sometimes, I visit the park to enjoy nature, which brings me peace and tranquility. I also practice balance with sticks from Home Depot and use my bokken wooden sword whenever possible. There’s a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played in a while, but it’s good to have just in case. My dad introduced me and my best friend to tennis with Mr. Graves, and we always had a blast despite the hard work. I’ve had many fun times in this neighborhood, and although there are many stories, these are the ones that stand out to me, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. It doesn't particularly stand out in South Carolina, but it has a significant influence on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, proudly displayed on the town's welcome sign. The town mainly consists of farmland, dominated by either peach orchards or cattle. Houses outside the main part of town are widely spaced, mostly two stories tall with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not, these houses are set back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the main part of town, there is a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where the only stores in the town are located. There are three places offering "fast food": Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, but it closed recently. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug, interestingly best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, commonly known as IGA. Although it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many people only stop for one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville to purchase most of their groceries. The most popular store in town is Dollar General; it sells a wide range of everyday items and is often busy from opening until closing! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman well-known in the community. The store has been in Johnston for many years and even employs two movers to deliver purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store is a small pet grooming shop called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a variety of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, and bathing. Both a doctor's office and a veterinary clinic are located away from the main part of town; they are both small practices, yet well-equipped to serve the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school named Johnston Elementary School. Once students complete fifth grade, they must attend middle and high school in the next town. Technically, there are no parks within the town, but they are currently in the process of creating a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide families with more outing opportunities and to attract more visitors and potential residents. Admittedly, there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, walking areas for pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this, it is a nice town, so small that you could pass through in the blink of an eye without noticing!

I live in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, so we have a bit more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise, it's a peaceful neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I've become familiar with most of the residents. People are usually busy with yard work and other daily tasks. In winter, we sled down a hill on the side street. Our house is located at the front corner of the street, allowing us to see everyone coming and going and recognize the cars around here. Whenever we spot a strange vehicle, we notice it. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs. Kids ride bikes and play, as you might expect. Since we work from home, we're at home a lot. There are four of us: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. I think others are used to seeing us come and go as well. We enjoy playing outside, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we grill on our back deck, which fills the air with a pleasant barbecue aroma. It seems like someone is always mowing the lawn, and we hear lawnmowers nearly every day from March until about October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood has many trees because it was originally a wooded area, providing lots of shade, but also plenty of leaves in the fall. This means we rake and burn leaves annually. I also like the smell of burning leaves, a nice indication that fall has arrived. Recently, we haven't had much of a winter, so it feels like a prolonged fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door unless someone knocks, which is rare. I enjoy working on my truck or other projects in the garage, and when the doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. During holidays, it's quite quiet here. On Thanksgiving, some neighborhood families have visitors from out of town, resulting in extra parked cars. It's the same on other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is right in the center of the high desert, where there's dirt everywhere. Unless someone has lived here, they might not truly grasp the constant sight of brown, and when you see a lawn, you know that person is spending a lot on upkeep. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were widely spaced. Now it's pretty much the same, but there are many new developments. Honestly, this place looks more like a city every day, but I suppose most places are changing that way. Most of the time, people are very friendly, but like any city, there are good and bad areas. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly older people, so it's a nicer area. The stores around here are mainly chain stores like Food For Less and Smart & Final. If you want upscale options, you have to travel; I never see any Whole Foods or similar stores. In my city, the most common job, in my opinion—not based on official data—is construction. This is probably because the city isn't very developed yet, with lots of open space to build on. That worries me a bit; I like things as they are now. I left a big city and don't want to go back. Speaking of construction, that's also the field of my full-time job; I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I like about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, including the unique beauty of the desert itself. The high desert's climate and geography have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to different wildlife. Human residents should take time to learn about the non-human residents sharing this environment for safe and harmonious coexistence. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, and they are all fascinated by lizards and desert bugs. As I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As for attractions, we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert, offering a different kind of experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair enriches your visit with the right mix of activities and fun, the Victorville way. Also, visit nearby Wrightwood to see snow-covered mountains and take winter sports lessons to complete your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's societal and industrial development.

When I am asked to describe my neighborhood, I am sure my response is somewhat unique. While others who answer this question are likely homeowners with their own lives, my situation is a bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I reside, and the people living in my dormitory to be my community. I also view the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some similarities with more traditional concepts of a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, mine has houses, residents, shops, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before exploring the houses, it's best to clarify the types of housing available here. There are three types of housing in my vicinity: apartments, actual houses, and dormitory houses. First, in the apartments, there are usually 2 to 4 people per room, with about 4 to 6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type typically has two floors, so on average, about 20 people live in each building. Second, there are actual houses available for school-affiliated individuals to rent. These typically have 2 to 4 bedrooms and are often occupied by alumni. However, there are only a few of these houses scattered throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms that house hundreds of students. In these rooms, usually two people share a room, though there are exceptions, and this is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, we can move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, which is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages living here. Most professional staff live in the houses within the neighborhood, while new students stay in dormitory-style housing and older students in apartment-style housing. Simply talking about these people doesn't do them justice, so it's better to move on to the shops and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school is essentially a self-contained neighborhood, it has a variety of shops and a single park. The shops offer dining options found in any neighborhood, combined with the school's own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Thus, anything needed can be found within the boundaries of my neighborhood! Additionally, the park is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, kept clean and safe by all the members of my community.

There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downhill, and my house is right at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "workout hill" because many joggers enjoy running up it during their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road has some potholes and can feel a bit unsafe to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires around the block look worn out. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and debris often knock down the power lines, and the constant repairs make them look patchwork. There are many tall evergreen trees wherever you look. However, people here dislike the trees because they block the ocean view. That's why many houses are built high on the hill, with large glass-fronted second stories rising one after another to capture the bay view. It's beautiful at sunset when the water seems to be lit from below and the sky turns orange. However, it's often cloudy, so most of the sunlight is seen through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. Once, I left my car parked in my driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. It took me three hours to scrape it all off. There aren't many children around where I live, even though there's a school just a few blocks away. Most people in my neighborhood are older, many retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting on lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open, you risk them sneaking into your house. I once found one in my living room and had to shoo it out the front door. Rabbits run wild in the area. Some are quite large, and gardeners dislike them because they dig up plant roots and burrow into lawns. My cats love them, though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also have the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There's not much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can clearly see the opposite shoreline even through the mist on most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you won't have trouble finding it! Public transportation is very convenient and is one of the most popular modes of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurst is quite an urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see a variety of Asian stores around you. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurst has seen an influx of Asian residents. As a result, you'll encounter an Asian-owned store on almost every block as you walk. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly popular. Coincidentally, these businesses are favored by local residents because the food quality in the supermarkets is excellent, the prices are lower, and importantly, it is very convenient. Near where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking distance of each other. This adds to the convenience of grocery shopping. I'm not saying Bensonhurst is solely populated by Asian residents; it is quite diverse, with immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. Most large and popular local businesses are Asian-owned. In addition to these, there's a recently renovated park nearby with about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for summer fun. Since we're in New York City, the parks are naturally very diverse. You will see diversity here, with people playing together harmoniously. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The buildings you find are primarily co-op living or condominium apartments. However, most living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are quite friendly, but it's very noisy. Every day, you'd hear cars blasting music as they drive by or revving their engines, waking you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, you should remain cautious. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people can be unpredictable. You might encounter people looking to cause trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I myself have experienced bullying in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. A recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Lastly, even though there's a fine in New York City for not cleaning up after your dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

To grasp the essence of Portland, Oregon, the first thing you need to understand is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial town motto, displayed on the back of a building that acts as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club—skirting legal boundaries in at least half of these ventures—is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this serves as a gentle reminder of Portland in the '90s and early 2000s, a time when the city was less known and less costly, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it's an invitation—come to Portland, where people still call you weird, but this time it's a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the constant rise of condos built for them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean embracing things usually not accepted. It doesn't imply we lack modern amenities or current challenges. Like the rest of the country, most of our goods come from China. There are countless ways to be weird or unconventional, but Portland has its share of the ordinary too. It has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Maybe weirdness means we take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many areas of Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. These free boxes, traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is discarding, can also be plastic bags or boxes. They often hold something magical, a perfect treasure for a passerby, surprisingly often. Free boxes usually have clothes and books, but they can contain anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood embodies what Portland means to me, although I'm just one type of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never consider picking clothes from a box on the sidewalk. They prefer goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or attending Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love a myriad of things. It's a city full of dream chasers, or those who dream of pursuing dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug issue. Drug problems are often rooted in mental health issues, and the constant rain throughout much of the year, coupled with dreary clouds, seems to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness issue, one that nobody seems to know how to tackle. The homeless are drawn by the social services Portland offers, which are better than most parts of the country, but our services are still lacking, as they are everywhere. The non-homeless population oscillates between compassion and resentment. In this, we aren't weird at all.

The mountains are ever-present. To the north, they bear witness to the sun's journey every dawn and dusk. Regardless of how much I might forget them or how busy I am with work and life, they remain steadfast, unaffected by life's troubles. On my most stressful days, they demand attention, and when I turn to them, they offer solace to my anxious soul, lending me the strength to continue, one day at a time. I moved here when I started my undergraduate studies, and it was the mountains north of the campus that first captured my heart. The university has its share of breathtaking buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold a part of my affection, but it's truly the mountains that reign supreme. The rest of the town has its own unique beauty. Countless cafés have been the setting for many caffeine-fueled study sessions. One can walk or take a bus a bit further to the downtown area, where the faded bricks of restaurants and office buildings envelop you in a sense of antiquity. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and energy as its neighboring city. This doesn't last for many blocks, as you can escape back to the serene small town by passing the library. This contrast of atmospheres in close proximity gives the city a wondrous vibe, as if calling to be explored. It's easy to create many cherished memories here, each associated with a different part of town. Whether it's walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater the university provided tickets for. Alas, it's also home to many harsh memories, as all places in life are bound to have. The ponds, in particular, can be a fitting place for reflection and late-night crying sessions during an existential crisis, the latter of which I have more experience with. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each with its role, I couldn't help but ponder my own purpose as I navigated this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, the park, and the suburban houses, until I reached a main street. At that moment, the sun cast its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, there they were, as they always had been. The sturdy, towering mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and without words, they stirred my sense of perseverance.

At first glance, you might overlook it—after all, it's a residential area tucked behind a shopping strip, not a place you'd expect people to live. At least, not somewhere most would choose to reside. But if you venture behind the old, deserted Whole Foods and past the hotels that only fill up during summer family reunions, you'll stumble upon a lively community. On these streets, you'll find a few apartment complexes—lined up like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls along the road. The first set of apartments has been in the news for some unsavory incidents, so let's not dwell on them—appearances can be misleading, after all. However, the apartments next to that and the two complexes beyond are part of a world few locals know. Across from these complexes is a satellite campus of a community college—quiet buildings stand watch over the road as students, coffee in hand, yawn into their day at 7 a.m. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters grumble at the traffic when attendance is high. The road intersects another residential street, flanked by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from unfortunate fractures. The rehab center features cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan stirring the warm summer air. Children race across the park's grass, tumbling and spinning, while bees lazily hover in the flower patches nearby. Retirees walk their dogs on the path, frowning at the skateboarders and nodding at teenage girls gossiping by the playground about boys and the latest YouTube trends. In the strip mall next to the park, there's a sushi place with affordable food that never seems too busy—a swim supply store sits beside it, with a nail salon tucked in between. You could prepare your pool for the season, get a manicure, and enjoy some hibachi chicken all in one trip—the charm of a strip mall. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt spot where teens, clutching cold cups covered in toppings, show off skateboard tricks and vape, thinking it's the coolest. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where time and much else seem to stand still.

My neighborhood is quite intriguing. Most houses are single-family homes, but there are some that have been divided into two parts, while still being connected, if that makes sense. My house has a small yard in front and a small driveway to the left. Like most others, it reminds you of a time not too long ago when suburban living was the American dream. This dream once embraced the people of this country, but now it seems to be slipping away. Yet, my neighborhood and many others still exist, still reaching out to us and visitors, saying the dream is still alive and we are holding onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the little yards aren’t maintained as they used to be, but there are still one or two cars in every driveway, and the youth still play as if the world around them is their entire existence. The public school here, standing for nearly 90 years, still stands, seemingly conjuring up a future for today's youth while stirring nostalgia among older residents. Churches are few and mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All the homes look different, yet feel the same. There’s a large supermarket called "Super A," owned by a large Yemeni family, who are possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids usually play football, only stopping to let cars pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations, and many can tell stories of a past where everyone knew each other. There used to be a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, kids stopped wanting to be the Karate Kid, so it’s now a pharmacy because, as they say, medicine makes everything better. There’s also a small movie theater that plays old films at a discount, spared from crowds due to the youth's disdain for its lack of new releases, but favored by the elders who see it as a small price for a night out, without kids, of course. There's a single expressway passing through my town, though the exit and entrance are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition for an exit in our town. The youth supported it, but the elders refused. They believed having the expressway in our town would ruin it, and eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They're building a new high school, and we're trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I live in a big city, my neighborhood is very diverse. Residential areas are spread out seemingly at random among commercial areas where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses are offices, while others are shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There are plenty of new restaurants to try and shops to visit. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by major corporations, small boutiques are also becoming more popular. These are not only in malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and peaceful if not for so many attractions. There are a couple of nearby parks, and I've noticed people often visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of people, there's quite a bit of diversity in my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Beyond my immediate neighborhood, there are many more people of various races and backgrounds, although they sometimes form their own small communities within the city. We have areas like Korea Town, Chinatown, Little Armenia, and more, just a few miles away. However, even a few miles can be a long drive. Driving just 10 miles can sometimes take two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain places of interest are nearby, the city is vast, and people generally don't prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we have some of the worst traffic in the world, and finding parking is challenging almost anywhere. Ironically, there's been a lot of construction in recent years as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes and smaller apartment buildings and condos. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even in my immediate neighborhood, so there is no shortage of diversity in housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood consists of people of different ages, and to be honest, I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors. It's not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many childhood memories of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all around my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields stretching across the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be shocked by the sparse open landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house—she had never seen so much open space in her life. Amazed by the abundance of cornfields, I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it lies the small community where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco, each with at least half an acre of land that everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, the yards bloom with annually planted flowers and midwestern trees that change with the seasons. The driveways are lined with high-end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good wash. Continuing down the road towards my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside, greeting everyone with a friendly face. He often spends the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, but he is always sincere and an amazing person with a unique history. As he has aged, he has lost some of his sharpness. In his past, he was a doctor and often blends into the grass with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese abound and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there's a small stream feeding into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across a handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (which mostly involved chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child to play with. Winters in my small town can be harsh, yet there's nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into a barren wilderness. The trees, once vibrant with pink, purple, and orange flowers, turn into bare skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is adorned with snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen. My sister and I often fought as kids, and in winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland, we played pretend at a time when nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it.
